metadata.title: All-Solid-State Fiber Supercapacitors with Ultrahigh Volumetric Energy Density and Outstanding Flexibility

sections.text:

sections.heading: Volumetric Energy Density and Outstanding Flexibility
Zhenghui Pan, Jie Yang, Qichong Zhang, Meinan Liu, Yating Hu, Zongkui Kou,
Na Liu, Xin Yang, Xiaoyu Ding, Hao Chen, Jia Li, Kai Zhang, Yongcai Qiu,
Qingwen Li, John Wang,* and Yuegang Zhang*
sections.text:
DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201802753
due to their mechanical flexibility in volume and shape requirement, high power density, rapid charge/discharge rate, long cycle lifetimes, and remarkable stitchability.[1–8] However, one of the key challenges of the FSCs in the light of their practical applications is to increase their volumetric energy density to the value approaching to or even exceeding those of microbatteries without sacrificing the power density, cycle life, and other performance para meters.[9–15] Both the energy and power density of a SC is strongly dependent on the operating voltage, that is, V2 (E = 1/2 CV2 and P = V2/4RESR, where C is the capacitance of the device, V is the operating voltage, and RESR is the equivalent series resistance).[16–25] Therefore, increasing the voltage window would be an effective approach to achieve highefficiency FSCs.
To this end, enormous efforts have been devoted to the fabrication of asymmetric FSCs (AFSCs) which make full utilization of the operational windows of both the
positive and negative electrode materials.[25–32] Nevertheless, the intrinsic characteristic voltage of water splitting (1.23 V) means that an aqueous electrolyte is limited to a potential domain of around 1 V, thus constraining the operating voltage to a maxi mum of 1.8–2.0 V,[28–33] which is indeed lower than that of
Fiber supercapacitors (FSCs) represent a promising class of energy storage devices that can complement or even replace microbatteries in miniaturized portable and wearable electronics. One of their main limitations, however, is the low volumetric energy density when compared with those of rechargeable batteries. Considering the energy density of FSC is proportional to CV2 (E = 1/2 CV2, where C is the capacitance and V is the operating voltage), one would explore high operating voltage as an effective strategy to promote the volumetric energy density. In the present work, an all-solid-state asymmetric FSC (AFSC) with a maximum operating voltage of 3.5 V is successfully achieved, by employing an ionic liquid (IL) incorporated gel-polymer as the electrolyte (EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFP). The optimized AFSC is based on MnOx@TiN nanowires@carbon nanotube (NWs@CNT) fiber as the positive electrode and C@TiN NWs@CNT fiber as the negative electrode, which gives rise to an ultrahigh stack volumetric energy density of 61.2 mW h cm−3, being even comparable to those of commercially planar lead-acid batteries (50–90 mW h cm−3), and an excellent flexibility of 92.7% retention after

sections.heading: 1000 blending cycles at 90°. The demonstration of employing the ILs-based electrolyte opens up new opportunities to fabricate high-performance flexible AFSC for future portable and wearable electronic devices.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid advancing of miniaturized portable and wearable electronics, micro-supercapacitors (micro-SCs), especially those tiny fiber SCs (FSCs), have captured tremendous attention
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1802753
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1802753 (2 of 10)
most commercial electric double-layer capacitor (EDLC) (2.5 V). Ionic liquids (ILs), normally consist of organic cations and anions, are promising electrolytes that can enhance the performance of SCs owing to their wider electrochemical windows, high ion conductivity, high thermal stability, and nonflammability.[34–38] Indeed, various ILs have been studied for flexible SCs based on carbon materials and transition metal oxides/ nitrides, which allows for the expansion of their maximum cell voltage (up to 3.2–3.5 V), and consequently the improvement of their maximum energy/power density.[39–43] Unfortunately, on the one hand, most of the flexible SCs based on pseudocapacitive materials (e.g., MnO2) suffer from low specific capacitance, because of their poor electrical conductivity and low utilization rate in association with the dead volume. On the other hand, this drawback can be overcome by depositing ultrathin MnO2 nanosheets on highly conductive nanostructure, such as nanowires (NWs).[44–50] Therefore, an appropriate combination of 3D MnO2@conductive NWs processing high pseudocapacitance as the electrode and ILs electrolyte with a wide potential window (3.2–4 V) could render a sharp rise in the energy density and overall performance of flexible SC.
In this work, we successfully designed and fabricated highperformance all-solid-state AFSCs with a maximum operating voltage of 3.5 V by adopting MnOx@TiN nanowires@carbon nanotube (NWs@CNT) fiber as the positive electrode and C@ TiN NWs@CNT fiber as the negative electrode, and employing an IL of EMIMTFSI incorporated gel-polymer electrolyte (EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFP). Note that the usage of IL electrolyte in FSCs has not yet been reported up to date. The fully packaged AFSC exhibits an ultrahigh stack volumetric energy density of 61.2 mW h cm−3, which is higher than those FSCs ever reported and even comparable to those of commercially planar lead-acid batteries (50–90 mW h cm−3), while simultaneously
maintaining a high power density of 10.1 W cm−3 as well as excellent flexibility (92.7% retention after 1000 blending cycles at 90°).

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
The all-solid-state AFSC with EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFP gelpoly mer electrolyte was successfully assembled and the fabrication process is schematically illustrated in Figure 1. CNT fiber with excellent electrical conductivity and remarkable structural flexibility was directly used for the current collector. First, the TiN NWs@CNT fiber was fabricated by a modified hydrothermal process, and subsequently annealed under ammonia at 800 °C for 1.0 h.[51–53] Then, MnOx nanomaterials were then deposited on the as-obtained TiN NWs@CNT fibers to obtain MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode by electrochemical deposition. Meanwhile, C@TiN NWs were also synthesized on CNT fiber by a hydrothermal coating and further annealed to form a thin layer of carbon. Finally, the AFSC was successfully assembled by twisting the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT positive electrode and C@TiN NWs negative electrode together after coating them with a thin layer of EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFP gel electrolyte, which is presented in the inset of Figure 1 and Figure S1c (Supporting Information), where the optical and scanning electron microscope (SEM) images are shown. Interestingly, such AFSC device with an operating voltage of 3.5 V is demonstrated by powering of 3.3 V blue light-emitting diodes (LEDs).
The initial CNT fiber with a uniform diameter of around 125 µm has a compact structure, which is fabricated by twisting CNT strips (Figure 2a and Figures S1 and S2a, Supporting Information). Figure 2b,c shows the typical SEM images of the
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1802753
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1802753 (3 of 10)
as-prepared TiO2 NWs with diameter of ≈150 nm, which are aligned and densely grown on the whole surface of CNT fiber. After nitridation, there is no obvious morphological change in TiN NWs structure, as presented in Figure 2d and Figure S2b (Supporting Information). Figure S3 (Supporting Information) compares the typical stress–strain curves of pristine CNT, TiO2 NWs@CNT, and TiN NWs@CNT fibers obtained under the same experimental conditions. It is noted that TiN NWs@CNT fiber has an excellent tensile strength of 330 MPa, which is of great importance for further fabrication of the flexible AFSC. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results confirm the transformation of rutile TiO2 to cubic TiN (Figures S4 and S5, Supporting Information). The lattice fringes of 0.240 nm in the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image corresponded to the (111) plane of cubic TiN phase (Figure S6, Supporting Information), giving further confirmation on the successful conversion of TiO2 NWs to highly crystalline TiN NWs.[53]
Considering the unique structure and excellent conductivity of TiN NWs, one concludes that the TiN NWs@CNT fiber should be a promising scaffold for depositing active materials. In this work, a thin layer of MnOx nanosheets was directly electrodeposited on the surface of the TiN NWs@CNT fiber. Figure 2e,f shows that
the electrodeposited MnOx nanosheets are completely covering up on the surface of TiN NWs. More details about the MnOx@ TiN core/shell nanocomposites were investigated by TEM. As shown in Figure 2g, it can be found that the TiN NWs are uniformly wrapped by numerous MnOx nanosheets. Moreover, the HRTEM image (Figure 2h) of MnOx edge view identifies the lattice spacing of 0.248 and 0.489 nm, well matching up with the interplanar spacing of (211) and (200) planes of tetragonal Mn3O4,[54,55] which is consistent with the XRD results (Figure S7, Supporting Information). Figure 2i further collects the elemental distribution of the MnOx@TiN. The hierarchical core/shell nanostructure was unambiguously verified with that Ti and N elements located in the core, while Mn and O elements are mainly distributed in the shell. In addition, the weight content of MnOx and TiN was estimated to be 35.38 and 64.62% in the MnOx@ TiN NWs nanocomposites from energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), which is also confirmed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) result (Figure S8, Supporting Information).
Variation in geometric shape of the constituent ions in different ILs can lead to the different interactions with MnOx, accordingly affecting the pseudocapacitive capacitance. Therefore, we first investigated the influence of imidazolium-based IL electrolytes on the performance of MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1802753
Figure 2. a) SEM image of the initial CNT fibers. b,c) SEM images of TiO2 NWs@CNT fiber electrode at high magnifications. d) SEM image of TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode. e,f) SEM images of MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode at high magnifications. g) TEM image and h) EDS element mappings for Ti, N, Mn, and O of MnOx@TiN NWs core/shell nanocomposites. i) A HRTEM image MnOx shell which is taken from the red circle of (g).
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1802753 (4 of 10)
fiber electrode, and the results show that the optimized IL is 1-ethyl-3-methyl-imidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (EMIMTFSI) (Figures S9 and S10, Tables S1 and S2, Supporting Information); therefore, the correspondingly prepared 1 m EMIMTFSI/AN is used as the electrolyte in the following electrochemical measurements using a three-electrode system. For comparison, the MnOx@CNT fiber electrode is also studied (Figure S11, Supporting Information). From Figure 3a, it can be clearly observed that the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode shows superior electrochemical behavior, as evidenced by the higher current density, comparing to the MnOx@CNT fiber electrode. Due to the highly crystalline TiN NWs with a superior electrical conductivity of 4000–55 500 S cm−1, which would be favorable for charge transport.[56,57] Indeed, the MnOx@ TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode only shows a small initial voltage drop (IR) of 0.032 V, as seen in Figure 3b (0.127 V of the MnOx@CNT fiber electrode), from which one can derive the equivalent series resistance (RESR) of 3.27 and 12.96 Ω for the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode and MnOx@CNT fiber electrode, respectively, which is also well consistent with the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement result (Figure S12, Supporting Information). In Figure 3c, the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode is further investigated over a range of cyclic voltammetry (CV) scan rates of 0.01–0.5 V s−1 in the voltage window of 0–3.5 V. All CV curves exhibit quasi-rectangular shapes without obvious redox peaks, even at a high scan rate of 0.5 V s−1, suggesting the ideal capacitive behavior and desirable rapid charge/discharge property of our MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode. Rate capability constitutes a key factor in determining the SCs electrodes for practical applications, which can be evaluated from the symmetry and resistance drop value of the galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves. Typical GCD curves of the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode at different current
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1802753
Figure 3. a) CV curves and b) GCD curves of two different fiber electrodes. c) CV curves under different scan rates and d) GCD curves at different current densities of the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode. e) Comparison of volumetric capacitances versus different current densities for three different fiber electrodes. f) Cycling stability of the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrodes as a function of cycle number under a current density of 2.0 A cm−3.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1802753 (5 of 10)
densities of 0.5–5.0 A cm−3 as shown in Figure 3d. These near linear and symmetric triangular curves again indicate the excellent capacitive characteristic and good reaction reversibility of the fiber electrode. The volumetric capacitances of the MnOx@ TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode were derived from these GCD curves, and values as high as 776 F cm−3 were achieved at a current density of 0.5 A cm−3 (Figure 3d), which is 114% higher than the corresponding MnOx@CNT fiber electrode. Interestingly, the achieved volumetric capacitance (776 F cm−3 at 0.5 A cm−3) is also superior compared to most reported values, RGO+CNT@CMC (632 F cm−3 at 0.01 mA cm−2),[8] MnO2@ PEDOT:PSS@CNTs (478 F cm−3 at 0.05 A cm−3),[28] and MoS2@CNTs (334 F cm−3 at 0.5 mA cm−2),[50] as presented in Table S4 (Supporting Information). Such excellent performance of the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode derives from their large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area and mesoporous structure (Figure S13, Supporting Information), which can facilitate efficient diffusion of electrolyte to the active materials. Furthermore, the volumetric capacitance of the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode remains at 620 F cm−3 at the high current density of 5.0 A cm−3, demonstrating its superior rate performance. The cycling performance of the electrodes at a high current density of 2.0 A cm−3 is shown in Figure 4h. The MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode exhibits great cycling stability, that is, 93.6% of the initial capacitance retention after 20 000 cycles, much better than that of 76.4% for the MnOx@CNT fiber electrode (Figure S14, Supporting Information). The excellent cycling stability of MnOx@TiN
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1802753
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1802753 (6 of 10)
NWs@CNT fiber electrode can be attributed to the core/shell morphological feature and crystalline nature of MnOx@TiN NWs are not affected after 20 000 GCD cycles (Figure S15, Supporting Information).
To better understand the mechanism behind the excellent performance of our MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode, synchrotron X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was used to elucidate the electronic structure change of MnOx in their unique fiber nanostructure. Obviously, the MnOx@TiN NWs@ CNT fiber sample shows a lower white line peak (peak A) than the MnOx reference sample (Figure S16, Supporting Information). It can be attributed to the electron transfer from the TiN NWs core to MnOx shell, which fills the unoccupied orbits in Mn to lower the absorption peak intensity and then forms an interfacial interaction between MnOx shell and the TiN NWs core.[58,59] Moreover, a peak shift to lower energy position of the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber sample can also be observed, further confirming the electron transfer from the TiN NWs core to MnOx shell. The interfacial interaction between the TiN NWs core and MnOx shell can significantly facilitate the charge transport and also show a synergetic effect in the nanocomposite to improve the fiber’s electrochemical performance. As a result, the highly conductive 3D TiN NWs in the fiber structure can not only provide a larger surface area of CNT fiber for loading more MnOx active materials, but also enable efficient electron transport for the MnOx shell. This well explains why the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber shows better performance than the MnOx@CNTs fiber in Figure 3. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to further elucidate the superior performance of our MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode, by taking the advantage of the excellent conductivity of the TiN NWs core and the high pseudocapacitance MnOx shell, which can attribute to the compatibility of MnOx active materials with EMIMTFSI electrolyte (the details can be found in Figures S17 and S18, Supporting Information).
To investigate the electrochemical performance of the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber for practical applications, an all-solid-state AFSC device is constructed using MnOx@ TiN NWs@CNT and C@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrodes in EMIMTFSI/poly(vinylidenefluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) gel-polymer electrolyte (the details discussion can be found in the Experimental Section and Figures S19–S22, Supporting Information). An EIS measurement was first performed to better understand the electrochemical behavior and the electrode kinetics of AFSC device in ionic liquid incorporated gel-polymer electrolyte. The series resistance (Rs) of the device was seen to increase from 2.35 Ω for the EMIMTFSI/ AN-based device to 10.74 Ω for the EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFPbased device, indicative of slightly larger electrolyte resistance in the gel-polymer (Figure S23 and Table S5, Supporting Information). Nevertheless, the RCT increase is minimal, suggesting the presence of a continuous ion pathway through the all-solid-state gel-polymer electrolyte. As shown in Figure 4a, the AFSC exhibits rectangular-like CV curves with a voltage window of 0–3.5 V at scan rates from 0.01 to 0.5 V s−1, thus implying its excellent reversibility and fast charge/discharge capability. Further interestingly, this 0.5 V s−1 charge rate of our AFSC based on MnOx active materials in IL gel-polymer electrolyte is comparable with the previous studies in which
ILs are used as a supporting electrolyte (Table S6, Supporting Information).
The electrochemical performance of the as-fabricated AFSC was further evaluated at different current densities from 0.1 to 5 A cm−3. The corresponding GCD curves are almost linear and symmetric (Figure 4b), again suggesting the excellent reversibility and capacitive behavior of the device. Based on these merits, our AFSC device delivers a high stack volumetric (areal) capacitance of 36 F cm−3 (360 mF cm−2) at 0.1 A cm−3 as presented in Figure 4c and Figure S24 (Supporting Information) (based on the whole device volume including two electrodes and electrolyte, see Figure S1, Supporting Information, for details); indeed, the value is superior to those most reported ones (Table S7, Supporting Information), such as MnO2@PEDOT:PSS//VN@C (35 F cm−3 at 0.3 mA cm−2),[7] MnO2@PEDOT:PSS//OMC (23.4 F cm−3 at 0.085 A cm−3),[28] and RGO+CNT//RGO+CNT (38.8 F cm−3 at 0.05 A cm−3).[31] A comparison of the stack volumetric power and energy densities of our AFSC (also based on the whole device volume including two electrodes and electrolyte) with those of previously reported FSCs and some commercially available energy storage devices is given in Figure 4d and Table S7 (Supporting Information). The highest stack volumetric energy density of 61.2 mW h cm−3 can be achieved by our AFSC at a power density of 0.2 W cm−3 and it can remain at 42.1 mW h cm−3 even at a high power density of 10.1 W cm−3. Significantly, such stack volumetric energy density value is even comparable to these commercially available lead-acid batteries (50–90 mW h cm−3).[12,13] The stack volumetric energy density is also much higher than those of other reports, including MnO2//PPy (2.98 mW h cm−3 at 0.08 W cm−3),[1,8,15,28,32,60–62] MnO2@PEDOT:PSS//OMC (11.3 mW h cm−3 at 0.03 W cm−3),[28] RGO/SWCNT//RGO/SWCNT (6.3 mW h cm−3 at 0.05 W cm−3),[1] RGO+CNT@CMC//RGO+CNT@CMC (3.5 mW h cm−3 at 0.018 W cm−3),[8] and SWCNT@C//SWCNT@C (3.7 mW h cm−3 at 0.018 W cm−3).[32] Figure 4e further compares the electrochemical performance of the recently reported FSCs. To the best of our knowledge, the as-prepared AFSC represents the highest volumetric energy density in FSCs to date. In addition, our AFSC also exhibits superior cycling stability with a high capacitance retention of 91.6% and unchanged EIS characteristic after 20 000 charge/discharge cycling at a current density of 0.5 A cm−3, which is also comparable to those of recent reports[63–65] (Figure S25, Supporting Information).
To explore the practical application potential of our AFSC in portable and wearable electronics, a series of mechanical flexibility tests were performed on the device. As illustrated in Figure 5a, no obvious change can be observed in the GCD curves under different bending angles from 0° to 180° at a current density of 0.5 A cm−3, indicating the exceptional flexibility of our devices. Even after being bent for 1000 cycles at 90°, there is still 92.7% of the specific capacitance retained (Figure 5b), further confirming the robust mechanical property of our AFSC device. It is encouraging that the GCD curves can also be maintained at various bending states when an AFSC device ≈20 cm long knitted into a cotton string glove (Figure S26, Supporting Information), demonstrating that the fiber-shape device has outstanding flexibility as efficient energystorage components for wearable devices. In addition, to meet
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1802753
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1802753 (7 of 10)Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1802753
specific energy and power needs for practical applications, the device can be integrated in series and in parallel to achieve even higher operating voltages and output currents, respectively. Figure 5c,d shows that the operating voltage and discharge time are doubled when two of such devices are connected in series and in parallel (Figure S27, Supporting Information), respectively, indicating the integrated devices are stable. Moreover, multiple AFSC devices are connected in parallel by incorporating a number of devices (up to 10) (Figure S28, Supporting Information). The overall capacitance of the assembled AFSCs increased linearly with the number of devices, showing excellent scalability (Figure 5e).
To further demonstrate promising application potential of our AFSC as an integrated green energy system, we used a fully charged AFSC to drive an overall water-splitting unit that is based on the NiCoP NWs@CNT fiber as the bifunctional oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts (Figure 5f and Figure S29, Supporting Information). As shown in Figure 5g, the ultrahigh energy density AFSC based on IL gel electrolyte can provide a steady output voltage of 3.5 V for the overall water splitting up to about 15 h, much longer than that of the AFSC based on aqueous gel electrolyte (1.8 V for 3.5 h). The O2 and H2 thus generated during the self-driven water splitting in 14 h were collected (Figure S30, Supporting Information), and the Faradaic efficiency for both OER and HER was calculated to be close to 100% with the H2:O2 volume ratio of 2.05:1.00, approaching the theoretical value of 2.00:1.00 during electrolysis. Furthermore, we have successfully demonstrated an all-day-long overall water splitting system (Figure 5h), by taking advantage
Figure 5. a) GCD curves of the device measured at a current density of 0.5 A cm−3 under different bending angles. b) Normalized capacitances of the AFSC device with the bending angles of 90° tested for 1000 cycles. c,d) GCD curves of two AFSC devices connected in series and in parallel, respectively. e) The relationship between total device capacitance and the number of AFSC devices connected in parallel. f ) IR-corrected LSV curves of the NiCoP NWs@CNT fiber for overall water splitting at the scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in 1.0 m KOH. The inset of (f) is SEM image of the NiCoP NWs@CNT fiber. g) Chronoamperometric response curves for the NiCoP NWs@CNT fiber for overall water splitting with our AFSCs. h) Voltage– time curve of the self-driven overall water splitting powered by a commercial Si solar cell (8 am to 6 pm, the day) and our ILs gel polymer based AFSC (6 pm to 8 pm, the night).
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1802753 (8 of 10)Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1802753
of a commercial Si solar cell providing sufficient energy for electrocatalysis as well as charge our AFSC over the period of 8 am to 6 pm (day time) and the as-charged AFSC offering a steady output voltage for overall water splitting at 6 pm to 8 am (night time). Such an uninterrupted solar-to-hydrogen conversion and storage system opens up exciting application opportunities for the development and application of renewable energy.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text: In summary, a novel fiber-type electrode consisting of MnOx@ TiN NWs@CNT core/shell nanocomposites was rationally designed and fabricated by a controllable process. The purposely aligned 3D TiN NWs with the superior electrical conductivity are favorable for efficient electronic transports, giving rise to a high volumetric capacitance of the MnOx@ TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode in the ILs electrolyte. As a proof-of-concept for practical application, a prototype AFSC with a maximum operating voltage of 3.5 V was constructed by MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber and C@TiN NWs@CNT fiber in an EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFP gel-polymer electrolyte. The as-assembled AFSC delivered an ultrahigh stack volumetric energy density of 61.2 mW h cm−3, which is the highest value ever reported for FSCs and even comparable to those of commercially available planar lead-acid batteries (50–90 mW h cm−3), while simultaneously maintaining a high power density of 10.1 W cm−3 as well as excellent flexibility (92.7% retention after 1000 blending cycles at 90°). Furthermore, we have demonstrated that multiple AFSCs can be integrated in series or in parallel to meet the specific energy and power needs. The achievement on this ultraflexible AFSC with high volumetric energy density provides a new pathway to bridge the gap between microbatteries and micro-SCs for miniaturized portable electronics.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Section
sections.text:
Preparation of TiN NWs on CNT Fiber: CNT fiber was initially treated in O2 plasma for 15 min at 100 W. TiO2 NWs were synthesized directly on CNT fiber (TiO2 NWs@CNT fiber) by a modified hydrothermal process according to the previous report.[51] Titanium nitride (TiN) NWs@CNT fiber was obtained by directly annealing the as-prepared TiO2 NWs@ CNT fiber in ammonia gas at 800 °C for 1 h.
Preparation of MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT Fiber: To make MnOx deposition easily on the surface of 3D TiN NWs@CNT fiber, the TiN NWs@CNT fiber was first immersed into 0.5 m HCl aqueous solution for pretreating 1–2 min. Then, MnOx nanosheets were deposited onto the TiN NWs@CNT fiber by a facile electrochemical deposition process in a mixed aqueous solution of 0.05 m MnSO4, 0.05 m CH3COONa, and 10% ethanol with a current density of 5 mA cm−2. A Pt wire and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) were used as the counter and reference electrodes. Finally, the MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fibers were washed with deionized (DI) water twice, followed by drying in vacuum.
Preparation of C@TiN NWs@CNT Fiber: In a typical preparation process, the TiO2 NWs@CNT fiber was immersed in a 0.04 m aqueous glucose solution for 10 h, followed by nitridation in ammonia at 800 °C for 1 h.
Assembly of MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT//C@TiN NWs@CNT Flexible All-Solid-State AFSC Based on IL Polymer Gel Electrolyte: The EMIMTFSI/ PVDF-HFP IL gel electrolyte was prepared by mixing 5 g EMIMTFSI and
5 g PVDF-HFP in 50 mL acetone. The mixture was magnetically stirred for at least 1 h at 500 rpm, until the polymer particles were completely dissolved and the solution became homogeneous. The subsequent evaporation of the acetone results in the formation of solvent-free gel electrolytes. After that, both MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fibers and C@ TiN NWs@CNT fibers were immersed into the EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFP gel electrolyte for 20 min and subsequently dried. Finally, the all-solidstate AFSC was assembled successfully by twisting these two electrodes together and allowed to dry overnight until the EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFP gel electrolyte solidified completely. Due to the sensitivity of EMIMTFSI IL to air and water, all the devices preparation procedures were carried out in an argon-filled glove box with the moisture of <1 ppm.
Preparation of the CoNiP NWs@CNT Fiber: The cobalt-nickel oxide (CoNiO) NWs@CNT fiber was prepared by a hydrothermal method. First, 3 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 1.5 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 6 mmol of CO(NH2)2, and 2 mmol of NH4F were dissolved in 40 mL of deionized water. After stirring for 30 min, the CNT fibers were placed in the mixed solution and transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at a temperature of 130 °C for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting CNT fibers were rinsed with DI water and dried at 60 °C in air for 12 h. For obtaining the CoNiP NWs@CNT fibers by phosphidating, 1.0 g NaH2PO2 and the CoNiO NWs@CNT fiber were placed at the center and on the downstream side of the furnace, respectively. It was heated to 350 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 and held at that temperature for 2 h.
Structural Characterization and Analysis: The microstructure of each sample was characterized using a Quanta 400 FEG SEM and a Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin TEM. XRD was used to study the crystal structure of the sample with a Bruker D8 diffractometer. XPS characterization was performed on an Axis Ultra DLD X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. XAS experiments were performed at the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF, 14W)
Electrochemical Characterization: Electrochemical performance of the samples was characterized using a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments Inc.). In half-cell tests, the electrochemical measurements were performed in a standard three-electrode glass cell at room temperature with 1 m EMIMTFSI/AN aqueous solution as the electrolyte; MnOx@TiN NWs@CNT fiber electrode and C@TiN NWs@CNT electrode as the working electrode; Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode; and a platinum foil as the counter electrode. In full-cell tests, the AFSC was assembled to measure the device performance. Due to the sensitivity of EMIMTFSI IL to air and water, all the electrochemical characterizations were carried out in an argon-filled glove box with the moisture of <1 ppm.
Supporting Information Supporting Information is available from the Wiley Online Library or from the author.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201802753 due to their mechanical flexibility in volume and shape requirement, high power density, rapid charge/discharge rate, long cycle lifetimes, and remarkable stitchability.[1–8] However, one of the key challenges of the FSCs in the light of their practical applications is to increase their volumetric energy density to the value approaching to or even exceeding those of microbatteries without sacrificing the power density, cycle life, and other performance para meters.[9–15] Both the energy and power density of a SC is strongly dependent on the operating voltage, that is, V2 (E = 1/2 CV2 and P = V/4RESR, where C is the capacitance of the device, V is the operating voltage, and RESR is the equivalent series resistance).[16–25] Therefore, increasing the voltage window would be an effective approach to achieve highefficiency FSCs. To this end, enormous efforts have been devoted to the fabrication of asymmetric FSCs (AFSCs) which make full utilization of the operational windows of both the positive and negative electrode materials.[25–32] Nevertheless, the intrinsic characteristic voltage of water splitting (1.23 V) means that an aqueous electrolyte is limited to a potential domain of around 1 V, thus constraining the operating voltage to a maxi mum of 1.8–2.0 V,[28–33] which is indeed lower than that of Fiber supercapacitors (FSCs) represent a promising class of energy storage devices that can complement or even replace microbatteries in miniaturized portable and wearable electronics. One of their main limitations, however, is the low volumetric energy density when compared with those of rechargeable batteries. Considering the energy density of FSC is proportional to CV2 (E = 1/2 CV2, where C is the capacitance and V is the operating voltage), one would explore high operating voltage as an effective strategy to promote the volumetric energy density. In the present work, an all-solid-state asymmetric FSC (AFSC) with a maximum operating voltage of 3.5 V is successfully achieved, by employing an ionic liquid (IL) incorporated gel-polymer as the electrolyte (EMIMTFSI/PVDF-HFP). The optimized AFSC is based on MnOx@TiN nanowires@carbon nanotube (NWs@CNT) fiber as the positive electrode and C@TiN NWs@CNT fiber as the negative electrode, which gives rise to an ultrahigh stack volumetric energy density of 61.2 mW h cm−3, being even comparable to those of commercially planar lead-acid batteries (50–90 mW h cm−3), and an excellent flexibility of 92.7% retention after 1000 blending cycles at 90°. The demonstration of employing the ILs-based electrolyte opens up new opportunities to fabricate high-performance flexible AFSC for future portable and wearable electronic devices.
